title: Between 15 November 2019 and 21 August 2020, will the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) attribute a cross-market trading halt to a cyberattack?
preds: as stated before, far less than 1% chance of this happening in the remaining time.
far less than 1% chance of this happening in the remaining time.
Update for passing time. Reducing time spent for forecasting for a while.
going for soft round numbers on this one.
Seems less likely to happen now and there is less time for a suspension to happen. And less time for the NYSE to admit it.  But a Cyber attack could happen anytime, so possibility is not zero
I don't see this happening before closing date.

Starting with a base rate of zero. This has never happened before. Trading has stopped a few times in the past, such as 09/11/2001 attacks, and a technical glitch in 2013, as others have pointed out. Current Crowd Forecast is 1% chance, will use as my initial probability. Attribution to a cyberattack is also difficult.  Attack would have to be acknowledged, and made public.  Attack may or may not be attributed to a specific country, group, or source. Attribution to a country has huge political implications.  Non-attribution to a source gives appearance of incompetence. Even if NYSE is attacked and shutdown, this could be hidden. It could be attributed to glitch or error, and not an attack. Current financial and geopolitical instability from COVID-19 makes things more tense, slightly increases chances for attack.   I currently feel it is very unlikely, given base rate of zero, and many exceptions noted above. But many groups and countries could probably accomplish it if desired. So going with 1% instead of zero.

China and Russia have both infiltrated out electrical grids, so I think it is safe to assume they have infiltrated stock market systems as well.  I think there is a decent chance they will mess with that system in the coming months to sow chaos and confusion, attempt to interfere with the us election, or divert us attention away from their attempts to consolidate power elsewhere.
I am sure it is not for a lack of trying.
Lots of hackers out there with free time, and the exchanges are being politicized.
Lowering for passage of time and cyber attacks may have other focus through this period.
Guess the cyber-criminals are focused on lower hanging fruit now.
maintaining current forecast. Updating for passage of time.

It is very unlikely: - they can afford highest security standards
- the USA controls most of the IT-Suppliers
- running a secure trading platform is no magic

Bumping my estimate up. I'm concerned that with more high-level executives and traders working from home, including atthe large banks, that the risk of a successful attack goes up. What's the NYSE supposed to do when their entire business model is predicated on face-to-face interactions in a room in New York City? Going online seems like the natural option but would vastly increase the possibility of a successful attack.
and in this economy we would never hear about it...
Dropping back to an optimistic stance.
Lowering for passage of time. No system is hack proof.
Times are not normal. You cannot police a network working from home. I've been far too complacent, attoning.

i do think markets are concentrated on not letting the market drop to far, the guard is down which opens doors to cyberattacks. 
My opinion, but like anyoneone who knows alot about not knowing anything.
updating due to passage of time.
Lowering for passage of time. Stopped by algorithm but not cyber-attack so far.
It's election year, anything is possible
Possible. There was an attack about a year ago. https://www.investopedia.com/news/are-your-stocks-danger-getting-hacked/

August will be here in a few months.  There have not been many attacks that have been made public in the last year.  The few that have been made public involved stealing personal information from credit card companies and internet companies.   The attackers seem to have been common thieves.    I doubt the NYSE has much to worry about from countries, except maybe North Korea.  The other possibles would be China, Russia and some of the Arab countries.  Russia wants Trump to be re-elected in November; thus, they want the stock market to rise.  The Chinese sell us a tremendous quantity of goods that helps their economy; thus, they have no reason to bite the hand that -- partially-- feeds them.  The Arab countries was to keep sending us their oil, and MBS might be in real trouble if America elected a president who had a problem with the murder of an American resident in their Turkish consulate.   The attack would have to come from criminals or North Korea.   The criminals can likely find easier and more fruitful targets around the world.  North Korea frankly I do not understand.  They did attack Sony when they did not like a film.  Yet, I cannot think of a reason why they would attack the NYSE.  They want money from us in terms of foreign aid, which I understand they conduct missile and nuclear tests and then ask for money to stop them.  Thus, not too likely.
Moving off zero, not that I feel the threat is higher, just that it gets cold sitting at zero for months on end. And I must acknowlege that it could happen.
Other then the regular players, there may be some rouge elements that might decide to make a move.
Interested in our responses to cyber attacks

There was never a cross-market trading halt due to a cyberattack although the ability of the "bad actors" for doing so exists.  It won't happen unless there are definite benefits for such attacks, such as in the case of a war.  But currently the world has a much more urgent crisis to deal with - the coronavirus outbreak.  The two possible "bad actors" are Iran and North Korea.  Iran has reported infected cases.  North Korea probably has them too, but of course they are hiding this.
Not a high possibility but an ever present one.
Chances are so slim because there are so many other crises for possible attackers to focus on.

Institutions are being targeted every day - sometimes thousands of attempts - cyber security is an area of perpetual beta - attack and defense strategies evolve rapidly - if there was a longer time period I would probably increase the probability percentage - but by the end of the summer ...... to be reviewed

While there is a possibility of attack, it is unlikely that most adversaries of the Us would aggravate the government so blatantly; stateless, independent groups may not have the resources or infrastructure to target cyber-fortified US entities like the NYSE.  There is a chance, perhaps closer to the election, of some meddling from hacker groups with hidden state connections, but even then an attack big enough to cause a market shutdown is unlikely.  It may be more worth a hacker’s time to target other entities with large amounts of user data, such as telecommunications or social media companies.

Its happened before in 2009 & 2015.  Russia and other enemies have increased their cyber attack skill set and the US looks more and more vulnerable in many aspects so an attack should be expected in our election year.

It is possible. Especially with Iran or others who might want to disrupt US markets. https://www.zdnet.com/article/uk-government-investigates-possible-cyberattack-link-to-london-stock-exchange-outage/
https://www.investopedia.com/news/are-your-stocks-danger-getting-hacked/
Iranians were testing out some malware on Jonesboro, AR yesterday - but failed to take City Hall Off-line but that may just be because we still use DOS programming...
There is a chance but it’s more likely to happen as the election gets vloser

Everyone keeps improving their internet protocols as each new attack happens.  The stock exchanges and monetary funds are especially vigilant with white hat hackers continually testing their security.  I just feel an attack for effect is due around the election.  I just am betting our white hats are as good as the attacking person or government entity.
New non-lethal for of warfare. Weak cyber-security structure.
Would be hard to do in inferstructure  like I'm sure they have along with many many many many many firewalls.
Iran conflict. They’re likely to turn to cyber attacks and this could be a game-changing ‘world first’ event. Money will flow into crypto as a result.

A cyberwar with Iran is highly possible. Iran may have fewer restraints than other American adversaries like Russia, North Korea, or China, leading to attacks that are both “aggressive and unpredictable - to the point of being reckless.” Tehran is likely to lean on its proxy forces, including Hezbollah and Hamas, to effectively launch a full-scale attack.
Critical infrastructures like power grids and the financial system have long been seen as ripe targets for cyber warfare, but Iran may look to the Russian playbook, to focus any offensive campaign on President Trump himself, conducting influence operations including meddling in the upcoming U.S. Presidential election. 
The U.S. government has increased cyber capabilities dramatically over the years, Defense Department’s tools against any attack are unmatched, but the U.S. remains vulnerable in part because it doesn’t impose the kind of control Iran does over the internet.
BUT: To halt the NYSE from now to August 2020 seems unlikely, also considering that the damage inflicted on a Cyberattack to NYSE may be limited and it will be very unlikely that NYSE will make it public before this date. I gave a 3% because NYSE had quite a few cyberattacks in the past.
Thank you  @Japon  for the interesting links shared!

Between 15 November 2019 and 21 August 2020, will the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) attribute a cross-market trading halt to a cyberattack?
There are few parties who would gain by causing such a halt, there are also few parites who would have the capability to do so. 
I assume they are not the same subset or have better ways to deploy their capability.

I researched a bit on the subject in question before making the forecast, keeping it to the high limit of 1% in the current context. If I could, I would place it somewhere around or below 0.5%. I am basing this on the fact trading itself works primarily based on trust, if that's lost, everything crumbles. NYSE *publicly* admitting it has been hacked? How many times did that happen in the past? Twitter news, AI going wrong and so on news, yes, indeed, but even those are extremely rare to appear in public media vs the number of know and unknown attacks that (should) happen to NYSE or other markets. I have also read a few articles which finally led me to https://www.cogentoa.com/article/10.1080/23322039.2019.1645584 or, if the link doesn't work, try https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/23322039.2019.1645584.  There's something wrong with Figure 1, the graph showing the "Annual distribution of cyberattacks (accident date) on firms listed in the top five stock markets (1984–2017)". There's an obvious trend being formed in the past and it's easy to explain why the number of attacks grew: the internet and it's expansion & the number of people having access to it & the number of people that started to get into coding & the number of people wanting to get rich out of their knowledge OR the number or people having an interest in attacking those markets and finding a mean do to do so online. The wrong thing about the graph is... it suddenly turns back to the horizontal axis. Really? How can that be? Even the actual number of reported attacks is ridiculously low. That points to my first fact, there's no interest in making attacks to NYSE public. Another possible explication would be suddenly firewalls and security measures got so good they keep attackers off - they haven't. Some doors got closed in the past years, leading to obvious and low complexity vulnerabilities, but that's just a fraction of what can be accessed. The greatest vulnerability is that humans are operating the security systems in place and humans inherently have flaws. Even with the Iran events, North Korea shouts, Russia being more active and acting imperialistic like and so on, by 21 August 2020 to have the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) attribute a cross-market trading halt to a cyberattack is highly unlikely.

There seem to be a lot of increasing estimates due to the Iran issue.  I'm choosing to keep my estimate steady because I don't think the current round of issues with Iran have a material impact on the likelihood of a *successful* cyber attack on the NYSE. Maybe 1%. I'm sticking with the external view: successful attacks have been rare. Iran's cyber capabilities are said to be rudimentary compared to those of China, Russia, US and Israel (and I assume others like Germany). The financial exchanges have among the best cyber security teams in the private sector; they have closed networks; they have a limited number of users.
Iran is said to have the ability to launch a cyber attack the NYSE, and they are now looking for a way to attack the US.
It certainly would be an attractive option for Iran to do something like halt trading.

Increasing by 7% given that it is very likely that retaliation from Iran for the United States' killing of its top general will, at least in part, consist of cyber attacks [1,2,3]. Indeed, Iran has already targeted the NYSE in 2012 - however, this took the form of a relatively unsophisticated DDOS attack [4]. If such an attack were to occur again, it seems very unlikely it would result in a cross-market trading halt. But Iran does seem to have significantly strengthened its cyber capabilities [5] since then, so by now they might be capable of more powerful attacks - though I still think a cross-market trading halt would be unlikely because A) they still might not be capable of it and B) it is overwhelmingly likely that retaliatory Iranian cyber attack(s) will instead strike at other targets.  [1] https://www.cnbc.com/2020/01/03/iran-has-shown-a-significant-talent-for-cyberattacks.html
[2] https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2020/01/03/business/ap-us-iran-cyberthreat.html
[3] https://finance.yahoo.com/news/iran-capability-to-launch-cyber-attacks-on-very-short-notice-123311744.html
[4] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Ababil
[5] https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2020/01/03/cyber-attack-should-be-expected-us-strike-iranian-leader-sparks-fears-major-digital-disruption/
Such an event is extremely unlikely, because even those who might be able to to it (only very few are), have nothing to gain from it.

Cyber attacks are becoming more and more common and per Forbes financial institutions are high frequency targets.  However, who would  launch a cyber attack against the NYSE?  It would require someone with an awful lot of sophistication, either a government or a very knowledgeable organized computer crime group.  A solo hacker (someone weighing 400 lbs sitting on his  bed) is unlikely.  Which foreign governments would want to cyber attack? The obvious ones are North Korea, Russia and Iran.  There might be a few others, but I can't think of them right now.  North Korea would be by far the most likely.  They cyber hacked Sony when they did not like a movie so they probably have the ability but why would they?  Why do they launch missiles and develop nuclear weapons? I suspect because they want to be a player on the world stage without entering into a self-destructive war.  A cyber attack would do just that.  Russian likely would not do such a thing as long as their favorite president was in the White House and afterward probably would not want the resulting post-attack sanctions.   Next, Iran would.  They attacked Saudi Arabia recently with drones.  Iran hates us, but they probably do not have the ability and would likely attack a greater Satan first, e.g., Saudi Arabia or Kuwait.  There are some very sophisticated organized crime groups.  However, the NYSE is a very sophisticated target with sophisticated defenses.  No doubt the NSA and other organizations see the  NYSE as a likely target.  So, it would be difficult for someone to try to install ransomware or steal data, which are the usual goals.   Nevertheless, recently the City of New Orleans suffered a somewhat successful cyber attack but was unable to profit from it.  I imagine any organized crime group would considered any attack on the NYSE would have to be much more sophisticated and would provoke a severe response from the US intelligence agencies.  
They have smaller fish t to fry, but the New Orleans attack serves as one of many warnings.
Because of increasing cyberattacks on increasingly important entities
canadian lifelab breach. it can happen to the NYSE.
Cyberattacks are relatively frequent but rarely successful and even more rarely admitted publicly.
It seems a high likelihood of happening, but whether the stock exchange will attribute to that reason is less likely

NYSE has never in its history attributed a cross-market trading halt to a cyber attack so this would be a highly unprecedented event. The only cross-market trading halt driven by operational issues in recent years was in 2015, suggesting that these types of events are very unusual. On average 1 major US financial services firm per year  attributes operational disruption to cyber attacks again suggesting the chances that NYSE makes this attribution is low. Nonetheless, NYSE is likely to be a prime target for certain threat actors which could suggest a less than negligible chance of this event happening.
Even if it does occur, NYSE is unlikely to publicly acknowledge this without obfuscating the truth. Acknowledging that it has been successfully cyberattacked will be bad for business.

Taking a bit of a flyer on this one based solely on there being an opening for a nefarious entity to take advantage of diverted attention during next year's elections. Protecting the election from cyber attacks will be priorities 1-10 for cyber crime fighters and that could lead to opportunities in other areas. As FBI agent Fitzhugh told McNulty, "after 911 the Bureau doesn't care about drugs unless they are tied to terrorism."
A cyberattack is a highly unlikely event.

Redundancies are built into systems including concurrent backups so there should actually be a switch over to these data sources almost seamlessly even if there was an attack.  THe other reason is more fundamental - the only real people who can gain from a cyberattack on NYSE are nihilists - everyone else including assorted terrorists operate on teh basis of funding and funding dries up if the economy goes bad.  So why threaten the layér of golden eggs

- cyberattack is typical but they rarely leads to market trading halt
- I can imagine if there are 100 parallel universe there will be 1 market trading halt happened in 10 months
- if there are just 50 parallel universe, I think the chance of trading halt is a bit tends to unlikely

Individual companies more likely to be targeted than Wall Street itself. Old article. https://amp-businessinsider-com.cdn.ampproject.org/v/s/amp.businessinsider.com/new-york-cybersecurity-regulations-protect-wall-street-2018-2?amp_js_v=a2&amp_gsa=1&usqp=mq331AQCKAE%3D#aoh=15747454994612&amp_ct=1574745516879&referrer=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com&amp_tf=From%20%251%24s
Doubling my forecast.  Like as with a disease, there is much money to be made in the cure.

Even though i think it might happen, i need to research the technology used by the the NYSE for protecting the system. Knowing that cyber attacks happenes thousands of time every day, the question is how fast can that system detect the attaque before any harm is done?
So far it seems to work ok, because no breach was made. So what is the limit of that system.

Recent history increased the level of awareness on vulnerabilities, measures were taken to prevent this. The risk remains though.
Performing a successful attack would be complex. Risk vs benefit ratio not that high, other types of easier attacks are normally preferred.

- I have to believe that somebody, somewhere is attempting to attack the NYSE. Precedence: JUL-2009, JUL-2015 cyber attacks (so, +15% based on timing)
- I have to imagine the NYSE has done what it takes to prevent another occurrence save for DOS (-10%, so at 5%)
- But there's still a likelihood that hackers have already infiltrated and it is either undetected or not already reported (-2%, so at 3%)
- Regardless, NYSE would likely not admit to a cyber attack based on precedence in 2015 (-2, so at 1%)
- The last two attacks were reported in the month of July so, since this forecast includes the month of July, I'm going to give it another 1%. Just for fun.  So, 2% chance.
Very helpful perspective from @JC4841 [1], although I believe the probability of such an attack is even lower. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/924636
Some of the best security on the planet will continue to be in place at the NYSE and only an extraordinary event will beat it.

Base rate: It seems like trading on the NYSE has never come to a halt as a result of a cyberattack. There have been a few times when technical glitches [1] or geopolitical events [2] brought trading to a halt, but these were not related to cyberattacks. There have, however, been smaller-scale cyber attacks on stock exchanges across the globe, with one report finding that about half of exchanges were the target of cyber attacks in a given year [3].  The base rate suggests the likelihood of a cyberattack, especially one so disruptive so as to halt cross-market trading, is extremely low (I'd say nearly 0%). But it must be acknowledged that there are ongoing geopolitical risks that make such attacks on the NYSE possible - specifically, there is the possibility that state actors might target the NYSE as a way to target the U.S. In particular, both Iran [4] and North Korea [5] have shown that there are capable of mounting potent cyberattacks and they both have reason to target the US at the moment. As a result of this geopolitical risk, I am assigning this a probability of 3% instead of 0%.  [1] Technical glitch caused a three hour halt in 2013: https://www.ft.com/content/785e8ab2-258a-11e5-bd83-71cb60e8f08c
[2] The 9/11 attacks: https://www.ft.com/content/785e8ab2-258a-11e5-bd83-71cb60e8f08c
[3] https://www.reuters.com/article/net-us-cybercrime-exchanges-report/cyber-attacks-on-stock-exchanges-put-markets-at-risk-report-idUSBRE96F19A20130716
[4] https://www.forbes.com/sites/zakdoffman/2019/11/14/secret-iranian-network-behind-aggressive-us-cyberattacks-exposed-in-new-report/#47f4f38b579c
[5] https://nationalinterest.org/blog/korea-watch/cyber-attacks-are-north-koreas-new-weapon-choice-87526
